questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: As part of the national maternity benefit scheme, you have been tasked with conducting a study in a community of 5000 people.  What is the expected number of pregnant women in this community if the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people?
questions.solution:
The expected number of pregnant females in the given community would be 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 5000 x 30/1000 = 150 

Step 3: Since some pregnancies may not result in live births (abortions and stillbirths), a correction factor of 10% should be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies. Pregnancy wastage (i.e 10% of total live births) =10 x 150/100=15.

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live births + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (stage 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as the Billings method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Billings method of contraception is also known as the cervical mucus method (or ovulation method). 

It is a natural method of contraception. It is based on the observation of changes in the cervical mucus. At ovulation, the mucus is watery clear, smooth, slippery and profuse. After ovulation, it becomes thicker and scarce.

The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below:

questions.text: You are a doctor at a child health clinic. You will consider all of the following children as at-risk infants except:

choices.text: A 15-day-old baby with birth weight of 2.4 kgs
An 8-month-old baby being raised by a working mother

questions.solution:
The 2-month-old baby with 3 older siblings has a birth order of 4. Infants with birth order of 5 or more are considered at-risk infants.

The following are considered at-risk infants:

  • Birth weight < 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective natural method of contraception?
questions.solution:
The most effective natural method of contraception is the symptothermic method.

It combines:

  • Calendar method
  • Cervical mucus method
  • Basal body method.

In this method, if a woman is not able to identify one sign, she can double-check with her interpretation of the other signs.

questions.text: Which of the following was the world’s first international health agency?

choices.text: Health Organization of the League of Nations
United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The first international health agency to be established was the Pan American Sanitary Bureau (PASB) in 1902. 

This was followed by the establishment of the Health Organization of the League of Nations in 1923.

The World Health Organisation (WHO) was established on 7th April 1948.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the following tool:

choices.text: Malnutrition can be detected even before signs and symptoms appear
It provides an objective basis for policy making on child healthcare
It can be used to teach the importance of adequate feeding
It can be used to indicate proof of government aid

questions.solution:
The given image shows a growth chart. It is not used as proof of government aid.

The uses of growth charts are as follows:

  • Growth monitoring and diagnosis - can detect malnutrition before clinical features appear
  • Educational tool - to teach parents about the importance of adequate feeding.
  • Objective basis for planning and policy-making on child healthcares

questions.text: Which organisation gives the highest funding for reproductive health?
questions.solution:
United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) gives the highest funding for reproductive health. It works in the area of health and family welfare. 

It mainly works by:

  • Developing the national capability in manufacturing contraceptives,
  • Promoting population education programmes
  • Introducing innovative approaches to family planning and MCH care.

Sexual and Reproductive Health Awareness Day is organized on February 12th every year to raise awareness about sexual and reproductive health.  

The logo of the UNFPA is given below.

questions.text: How many goals does the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) comprise of?
questions.solution:
The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) are comprised of 17 goals.

These were set as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030.  These goals consist of a total of 169 targets. SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals on 1st January 2016. 

The 2030 agenda consists of five P's: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

questions.text: What is the average weight gain during pregnancy in Indian women with inadequate calorie intake?
questions.solution:
Weight gain during pregnancy in women with inadequate calorie intake is around 5 - 6 kgs.

Normally, a woman is expected to gain around 9-11 kgs of weight during pregnancy. An inadequate dietary intake can be suspected if the woman gains < 2 kg/ month.

Related Pearl: Recommendation for total weight gain during pregnancy by pre-pregnancy BMI

Category (BMI) Total weight gain range [kg(lb)]
Underweight (<18.5) 12.5 - 18 (28-40 lb)
Normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9) 11.5 - 16 (25-35 lb)
Overweight (BMI 25-29.9) 7 – 11.5 (15-25 lb)
Obese (BMI more than equal to 30) 5 - 9.1 (11-20 lb)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a vital statistic?
questions.solution:
Sex ratio is not a vital statistic, it is a population statistic.

Demographic indicators have been divided into 2 parts:

  • Population statistics include -
    • Population size
    • Sex ratio
    • Density
    • Dependency ratio
  • Vital statistics include -
    • Birth rate
    • Death rate
    • Natural growth rate
    • Life expectancy at birth
    • Mortality rate
    • Fertility rate

Related Pearl: Health Data

questions.text: Scope of modern concept of family planning services include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Screening for HIV infection does not come under the purview of family planning.

The modern concepts of family planning services include:

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g. cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counseling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counseling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions can OCPs be safely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is not a contraindication for prescribing OCPs.

Absolute contraindications of OCPs: (CULT)

  • Cancers - breast and genital
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Congenital hyperlipidemia
  • Undiagnosed AUB
  • Liver disease
  • Thromboembolism - past or present history.

Medical surveillance is required while prescribing OCPs if the patient is/or has:

  • Age more than 40 years
  • Chronic smoker and age over 35 years
  • Amenorrhea
  • Chronic renal disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Epilepsy
  • In the first 6 months of nursing
  • Gall bladder disease
  • History of infrequent bleeding
  • Mild hypertension
  • Migraine

questions.text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: As part of the National family planning program, you are conducting a study in a village to gather data on the efficacy of a new contraceptive. 20 out of 100 women became pregnant in the village despite using this contraceptive for a period of 2 years continuously. What is the pearl index of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 10 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 20. The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman.

Hence, the total months of exposure for 100 women are 24 x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/ Total months of exposure 

Hence, pearl index= 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the duties of the WHO?
questions.solution:
State health is not one of the duties of the WHO. It is the responsibility of the government.

Work and duties of the WHO:

  • Prevention and control of specific diseases
  • Development of comprehensive health services
  • Family health
  • Environmental health
  • Health statistics
  • Biomedical research
  • Health literature and information
  • Cooperation with other organizations

questions.text: What is potential support ratio?

choices.text: Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per child below 15 years or less
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older person aged 65 or more
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged >65 and younger person aged < 15
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged > 60 and younger person aged <15

questions.solution: The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. It is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which agency of the UN gives funds for technical assistance and has the following as part of its logo?
questions.solution:
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is an agency of the UN that gives funds for technical assistance. It has the following logo.  

Its main objective is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources to their potential. 

Some other agencies of the UN include:

  • UNESCO - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
  • UNEP - United Nations Environment Programme
  • UNHCR - United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees 

Their logos are given below.

questions.text: Millennium Development Goals were based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Millennium Development Goals were based on the United Nations Millennium Declaration. 

The Millennium Development Goals were eight development goals to be achieved by 2015 and were established at the turn of the millennium in 2000 by the UN.

It came to an end in December 2015 and was replaced by the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

On 1st January 2016, the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 agenda officially came into force.

The five P's of the new agenda are: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

The eight Millennium Development Goals are:

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about congenital syphilis?

choices.text: It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration
Infection of fetus most commonly occurs in the 1st trimester
Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication
Chances of transmission are lower if mother has late syphilis

questions.solution:
The chances of transmission of syphilis during pregnancy is highest after 6th month of gestation. It does not occur before the 4th month.

It is routine to test the mother for syphilis in antenatal clinics during her first visit. The chance of infection of the fetus is higher when the mother is suffering from early (primary or secondary) syphilis and are lower in case of late syphilis. Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication of congenital syphilis. It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the criteria for an urban Indian city?

choices.text: Having a density of 390 persons per square km
At least half of the adult male population employed in occupations other than agriculture

questions.solution:
In an urban area, at least three-fourths of the adult male population are employed in occupations other than agriculture.

In the Indian context, the urban areas are places:

  • having 5,000 or more inhabitants
  • having a density of not less than 1,000 persons per square mile or 390 per square kilometer
  • having pronounced urban characteristics
  • having at least three-fourths of the adult male population employed in pursuits other than agriculture

questions.text: A sexually active woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
questions.solution:
Today is a type of vaginal sponge that contains 9 – nonoxynol.

Today is a barrier contraceptive inserted vaginally. It has to be left in place for 6 hours after coitus. It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left in place for more than 24 hours (rarely).

questions.text: All of the following are non-contraceptive benefits of oral contraceptive pills except?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) do not confer protection against thyroid dysfunction.

OCP usage can confer protection against:

  • Benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma and fibrocystic disease
  • Ovarian cysts
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Ovarian cancer

questions.text: A juvenile delinquent was sentenced by the court to be placed in a center under the care of a doctor and psychiatrist. Which of the following fulfills this requirement?
questions.solution:
A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist and other trained personnel.

An orphanage or shelter home is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed.

Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis.

Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison. It is where boys > 16 years who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle are sent.

questions.text: Which agency of the United Nations has the following logo?

choices.text: United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The given logo is of the World Bank.

It helps less developed countries raise their living standards with economic support. The allocation of funds is decided by its Board of Governors.

questions.text: What is the denominator used in the formula for calculating the general fertility rate?

choices.text: Total number of women in the population
Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group
Total number of married women in the age group 15 – 45

questions.solution:
The denominator used to calculate the general fertility rate is mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations, on diagnosing a patient with which of the following diseases is notification not mandatory in all countries?
questions.solution:
According to the International Health Regulations(IHR), notification is not mandatory if a patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis in all countries.

It needs to be notified only by the countries where the public health impact is serious and there is a risk of international spread.

The government of India made the reporting of new cases of TB mandatory for all medical practitioners from 2012. An online web-based application named Nikshay is available for this purpose. Treatment providers are given a nominal cash incentive of Rs.1000/- per TB patient reported. 

Related Pearl: Diseases of International Significance

questions.text: What does the branch of medicine known as nosology deal with?
questions.solution: Nosology is the branch of medicine that deals with the classification of diseases.

questions.text: What was the 2017 target for the cure rate for multibacillary leprosy under the Programme Implementation Plan of NLEP?
questions.solution:
The 2017 target for cure rate for multibacillary leprosy was >95%.

The 2016 – 2017 targets under the Programme Implementation Plan of NLEP:

Indicator  Targets by March 2017 
Prevalence rate (PR) < 1/10,000  In 642 districts (100%) 
Annual new case detection rate <10/100,000 population  In 642 districts (100%) 
Cure rate in multibacillary leprosy  >95% 
Cure rate in paucibacillary leprosy  >97% 
Stigma reduction  50% reduction

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text:
Which of the following is carried out by the Drug Distribution Centres under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme for Malaria?
  1. Collection of the blood slides
  2. Distribution of antimalarial tablets
  3. Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) spraying operations
  4. Case-based surveillance
questions.solution:
The Drug Distribution Centres are only for dispensing anti-malarial drugs, under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) for Malaria. 

The organizational structure for the Anti-Malaria Programme is as follows:

  • Central Government: supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: is the key unit for the implementation of the programme.
  • District Malaria Officer: has the direct responsibility of IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC: has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi-Purpose Workers and ASHAs: carry out case-based surveillance and case detection in the community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: only for dispensing the antimalarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: collect blood slides in addition to the distribution of antimalarial drugs.

questions.text: As the medical officer in a Japanese encephalitis endemic area, which of the following measures would you not advocate for controlling its transmission?

choices.text: The use of Indoor Residual Sprays
Keeping pigs away from human dwellings
The use of malathion for outdoor fogging

questions.solution:
Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese Encephalitis (JE) as its vectors (Culex) are outdoor resters. 

Prevention and control of JE include:

  • Vaccination
  • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs act as important amplifiers of the virus.
  • Use of bed nets for personal protection.
  • Use of larvivorous fishes.
  • Using malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak.

questions.text: Which of the following measures for controlling malaria is the Urban Malaria Scheme mainly based on?
questions.solution:
The Urban Malaria Scheme is mainly based on anti-larval measures for controlling malaria. In Urban Malaria Scheme, urban areas with a population of >50,000 and a slide positivity rate of ≥5% are included. 

The vector in urban areas breeds in man-made containers. Therefore, anti-larval measures such as larvivorous fish and larvicides are used to control breeding as the primary method of vector control.

In rural areas, anti-adult measures, such as Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) is the primary method of vector control.

questions.text: According to the revised strategy for the eradication of kala-azar, which of the following drugs would you use across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection?
questions.solution:
A single dose of intravenous treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is used across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection. WHO will supply this drug free of cost. 

Drugs for Kala Azar:

  • Single-dose intravenous liposomal amphotericin B for all age groups and for pregnant and HIV co-infected patients.
  • Miltefosine- an oral drug, once daily for 28 days. Contraindicated during pregnancy, lactation, and in women who refuse contraception.
  • Combination of miltefosine capsules with paromomycin i.m, for 10 days. Contraindications are the same as miltefosine.
  • The drug of choice for Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is miltefosine 100mg orally per day for 12 weeks.

Ivermectin is used for lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Select the correct option regarding Intergrated Vector Management:

choices.text: Malathion is the insecticide of choice used for vector management
Larvivorous fish and larvicides are the main methods of vector control in rural areas
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets are provided in areas with API ≥5
Insecticide treated bed nets are supplied in areas with API ≥3

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated Vector Management initiative, Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥5.

Integrated Vector Management (IVM):

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are used as the main method of vector control in rural areas. The insecticide of choice will be the insecticide to which the local vector is susceptible as per the best available information. 
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT, and in DDT resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with malathion.
  • For larvae: 
    • Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥5.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC where you diagnose a patient with TB. Within how many days do you have to report it to the District Health Officer?
questions.solution:
The guidelines for TB notification under the RNTCP is within 30 days (a month) of receiving a new case. The notification must be done to the District Health Officer or the Chief Medical Officer of a District Hospital by the practitioner who diagnosed it.

Note: RNTCP has now been renamed to National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

questions.text: A rural medical officer implements Integrated Vector Management in his village. Which of the following measures of vector control would you prefer in a rural area?
questions.solution:
The measure of vector control preferred for rural areas is indoor residual spray (IRS).

Under integrated vector management (IVM), the preferred measures of vector control for

  • Rural areas include: Anti-adult measures, using indoor residual spray (IRS)
  • Urban areas include: Anti-larval measures, like environmental control by source reduction, chemical control (mineral oils, Paris green, synthetic insecticides, etc.), and biological control (fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebistes reticulatus which feed on mosquito larvae).

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy, who has completed a course of multi-drug therapy, presents with complaints of developing painful, tender, and raised lesions on his forehead recently as shown in the image below. What is the first-line treatment for him?

choices.text: Restart multi drug therapy and start thalidomide
Restart multi drug therapy and start prednisolone

questions.solution:
The presence of new erythematous and tender subcutaneous nodules in a patient with leprosy indicates that he has developed type II lepra reaction. It is also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) and the first line of treatment is prednisolone.

Multi-drug therapy (MDT) should not be restarted in patients who develop lepra reactions after the completion of treatment.

Prednisolone is started at a dose of 40 mg per day and gradually tapered by 5 mg every 2 weeks. 'Prednisolone card' is given when treatment is started. If the patient becomes steroid-dependent, then clofazimine is added.

The  key targets of the Global Leprosy Strategy 2021-2023 announced by WHO (Accelerating towards a leprosy-free world) are:

  • 120 countries reporting zero new autochthonous cases.
  • 70% reduction in the annual number of new cases detected.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million population of new cases with Grade 2 disability.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million children of new child cases with leprosy.

The current goal is the elimination of leprosy.

Related Pearl: Lepra Reactions

Lepra Reactions:

Type 1 Reaction

(Reversal/Upgrading)

Type 2 Reaction

(Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Mainly seen in the Borderline spectrum (BT, BB, BL)

Most severe in Borderline Lepromatous(BL) leprosy

 Mainly seen in LL(50%)>BL(15%)

Usually seen within 12 months of initiation of Multidrug Therapy

 Unrelated to Multidrug therapy. May occur before, during or after treatment

Type 4 Hypersensitivity

Due to enhanced cell-mediated response increased destruction of bacilli following treatment in reversal

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Primarily Humoral

(Immune complex Deposition in tissues and vessels)

Cytokine involved - TNF-α

Inflammation of existing skin lesions (red, painful edematous skin lesions) that may ulcerate

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

Thalidomide -most effective but not used first due to various side effects

questions.text: A patient on HAART presents with complaints of fever and expectorant cough for two weeks. What is the investigation to be ordered first?
questions.solution:
An HIV patient suspected to have TB is directly investigated by CB-NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test).

TB is a very serious infection in the immunocompromised and can lead to its most severe form as miliary TB and cause death. Since TB in HIV does not have its typical presentation, early suspicion and advanced diagnosis is the key to preventing mortality.

Diagnostic algorithm for TB:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the classification of malaria endemic states under the National Strategic Plan for Malaria?

choices.text: The states classified under Category 0  are in the elimination phase
The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
The states with districts reporting API in between 1-2 per 1000 population are in the elimination phase
The states classified under category 2 are in the phase of intensified control

questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the states under Category 1 of the NVBDCP to be in the elimination phase. 

Category 1 states are all states/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: Choose the false statement regarding the initiatives and strategies for tuberculosis.

choices.text: The Stop TB strategy was announced by the World Health Organisation
The STOP TB strategy has a target of ending TB by achieving an  incidence rate of <10 people per 10,000 population per year
The "Practical approach to lung health" was launched by the WHO for syndromic managment of patients with respiratory symptoms
The End TB strategy is a 20 year programme

questions.solution:
The Stop TB strategy was announced by World Health Organisation to reduce the global burden of TB by 2015 (and not ending TB). 

The End TB strategy is a 20-year programme with tagline “A world free of TB - Zero TB deaths, Zero TB disease, and Zero TB suffering”. It aims to:

  • end TB by achieving an incidence rate of <10 people/1 lakh population per year by 2035. 
  • reduce TB deaths by 95% and cut new cases by 90% by 2035.

 The "Practical approach to lung health initiative" was launched by the WHO as a syndromic approach to the management of patients who attend primary health care services for respiratory symptoms.

Ending the TB epidemic is also one of the targets of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) specifically under Goal 3 (to “ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages”).

Vision of End TB: A world free of TB- zero deaths, disease and suffering due to TB
Goal: End the global TB epidemic
Indicators Targets
  SDG 2030 End TB 2035
Reduction in no. of TB deaths compared with 2015 90% 95%
Reduction in TB incidence rate compared with 2015

80%

(<20/1,00,000)

90%

(<10/1,00,000)
TB-affected families facing catastrophic costs due to TB 0% 0%

WHO defines that "Tuberculosis control" would be achieved when the prevalence of the natural order of infection in the age group of 0-14 years is of the order of 1% (40% in India currently).

World TB Day is observed annually on March 24 to raise awareness about TB and efforts to end the global epidemic, marking the day in 1882 when the bacterium causing TB was discovered. This year's theme is 'Yes! We can end TB!', aims to inspire hope and encourage faster uptake of new WHO recommendations, adoption of innovations, accelerated action, and multisectoral collaboration to combat the TB epidemic

questions.text: Which of the following group of individuals would you not target under the programme represented by the logo shown below?
questions.solution:
The red ribbon shown is a part of the logo of the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) programme. Industrial workers are not included in the target population under NACO.

Target interventions for the control of AIDS transmission are done for:

  • High-risk groups like sex workers
  • Men who have sex with men
  • Transgender
  • Injecting drug users
  • Bridge population like migrants and long-distance truckers

The services offered through targeted interventions include detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases and condom distribution.

The logo of NACO:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the target interventions under National AIDS Control Organisation?

choices.text: Lubricants are given to  homosexual men
Clean needles and syringes are given to injecting drug users
Condoms are not given to bridge population
Opioid substitution therapy is given to Injecting Drug Users

questions.solution:
Bridge populations are supplied with condoms under the NACO target interventions. 

Target interventions: 

General:

  • Detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases
  • Condom distribution

For injecting drug users:

  • Distribution of clean needles and syringes.
  • Abscess prevention and management.
  • Opioid substitution therapy.
  • Linkage with detoxification and rehabilitation services.

For homosexual men and transgenders:

  • Provision of lubricants.
  • Provision of project-based clinics for sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most peripheral centre under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure?
questions.solution: Among the options given, Designated Microscopy Centre is the most peripheral centre.

questions.text: A physician follows the two test protocol for the diagnosis of HIV in a patient. It consists of:

choices.text: Western blot as the first test
Line immunoassay as the second test
HIV ELISA as the second test
Western blot  as the second test

questions.solution:
The two test protocol for the diagnosis of HIV consists of ELISA as the second test. If the initial ELISA is positive, a second ELISA is carried out. If the second ELISA is also positive, only then the case is reported to be positive.

Investigations involved in HIV testing strategies:

  1. ELISA/ rapid tests.
  2. Confirmatory tests with high specificity like western blot and line immunoassays are used in problem cases eg: indeterminate/ discordant cases of rapid tests.

In India, NACO provides western blot (WB) confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing. It is not used for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

Note: The western blot is used as a confirmatory test after 2 indeterminate primary tests (ELISA). It is essentially the third test used and does not fit into the two test protocol.

questions.text: As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under the National AIDS Control Programme, your duties include all of the following except:

choices.text: Estimation of total infection in the community
Estimation of total cases in hospitals

questions.solution:
As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance, the estimation of total cases in hospitals is not included in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under National AIDS Control Programme (NACO).

The aims of the HIV sentinel surveillance include:

  • Determine the level of HIV infection in the community.
  • Understand the trends of HIV epidemic.
  • Understand the geographical spread of HIV infection and classify districts according to epidemiological and vulnerability criteria.

These objectives are achieved by conducting annual cross-sectional surveys of the risk group in the same geographical place.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the PHC following a pinprick to his foot. He noticed it only after seeing bloodstains on the floor and complains of loss of sensation in his foot. After addressing the issue, the patient is referred to another centre. Where has he been referred to and why?

choices.text: For secondary prevention to a district hospital.
For tertiary prevention to a district hospital.
For secondary prevention to a district nucleus.
For tertiary prevention to a district nucleus.

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario of a patient with leprosy having neuropathy needs Micro Cellular Rubber (MCR) footwear, which is a form of tertiary prevention. He is to be referred to a district nucleus which supplies MCR footwear to patients.

questions.text: Before initiating treatment for a sputum-positive TB patient, the physician orders for Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test in order to test for drug resistance. Which anti-tubercular drug resistance is he checking for?
questions.solution: The Cartridge Based-Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT) is a molecular test for tuberculosis that detects the DNA of tubercle bacilli within 2 hours and mutations in the rpoB gene responsible for rifampicin resistance.

questions.text: The following two diagnostic techniques (A) and (B) were performed in a medical camp conducted for diagnosing malaria. Which is a true statement regarding these techniques?

choices.text: Image (A) - It is used for identifying the species of the malarial parasite
Image (A) - It is not the established method of choice for diagnosing malaria in urban areas
Image (B) - Antibody detection by this test is the method of choice for diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas
Image (B) - Bivalent type of this test was used for detecting Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax

questions.solution:
Image (A) is a thick blood smear and Image (B) is the Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT). Bivalent RDTs detect P. falciparum and P. vivax.

Thin blood smear is used to identify the particular infecting species. Thick blood smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.

Antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) are not the method of choice anymore in diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas. The Antigen detecting RDTs and blood smear examination are the recommended methods for diagnosis of malaria.

Note: According to the announcement by Union Health Ministry in April 2018, antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) for malaria is banned due to the high false-positive rates in endemic areas.

Malaria Antigen detecting Rapid Diagnostic Test kit:
